messageBody:
Just to make sure, that I understood your point of view:

In your opinion every viewable part of the view should be made accessible by
some method?
I have, e.g., a JTextField that displays some output text.
Thus I would add a method to give access to the String representation.

Did I get you right?

Toyin

----- Original Message -----
From: "Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Monday, June 11, 2001 3:50 PM
Subject: RE: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?


>
> > When unit testing guis you need to get access to the
> > components in the
> > view. If you develop under Borlands tool, you get default
> > access to the
> > graphical components on the protected level. As in VAJ
> > the components are
> > private I have to use reflection to gain access to them.
>
> I argue that there is generally a better way of testing the GUI than this.
> A real separation of model and view should allow for state-access methods
> that return some account of the state of the gui via states of it's
internal
> parts (usually in composite form).
>
> For instance, if I have a GUI that watches a directory and does some type
of
> processing on the things that come into that directory I might have the
> following:
>
> public class FileProcessorGUI{
> private java.awt.List filesList
> ...other private memebers...
>
> ...ctor's...
>
> public boolean isProcessing(){
> return directoryField.getText() != null &&
> !directoryField.getText().equals("") &&
> filesList.getItemCount() > 0;
> }
> }
>
> The isProcessing() method of course reflects that the processing is
> happening if all of the GUI elements meet this criteria, therefore you
must
> have some firing mechanism that would make sure that if this state were
true
> the processing really would happen.
>
> -Jason
